@tomcoates I gave up this morning and asked for an inspection copy (which reqd another form which unnecessarily took 15 mins to fill in, but hey). And yes I mail people my books all the time. Most of the issues here are bad UX and strategy, however, which is a bit lame for 2023
@dubber @unilibrary @ProQuest @Adobe If that's a Scandi beer, then it must've been a handsome return indeed.
#civicclock cc @bryanboyer

Another shout out for the new Circular Design Praxis project https://t.co/EuRzFjBLla with colleagues in Japan, and around which I wrote this contextual piece 'Spring to Autumn. Or, a ‚Äònew metabolism‚Äô for a circular society with Japanese characteristics' https://t.co/UpyZwvgeLm
(Of course the price of academic books is also appalling. Kindle editions at 150 dollars plus? And it‚Äôs not as if that goes to the writer.)

Online academic publishing is appalling. I get free access via @unilibrary but then the UX always falls apart. @ProQuest makes you use @Adobe Digital Editions, which is an embarrassment to all concerned. Sites for publishers like Taylor & Francis simply don‚Äôt work. What a mess.

@c_siggaard @bryanboyer As in crits and reviews? Not sure I did write something. And if I did, @bryanboyer would already know what I would say! I do remember a design publication (Disegno? Or equivalent) doing something about it? Will dig out. Also, this? https://t.co/05Ji9rhAOc

@TristanAR_ @BenPhillips_ANU @jryancollins Agreed on the second part (massively increased emphasis on sustainable public housing, via various means) but want to respectfully place a bit of caution on the first: as in, population growth rates are slowing, globally. We may already have a lot of the buildings we need.

@BenPhillips_ANU @TristanAR_ @jryancollins Yep. It was really about placing emphasis on the buildings we already have, rather than building anew. Also, whilst we need to hugely increase proportion of public and affordable housing either way, I‚Äôm suspicious of overall growth projections, given global population slowdown
(Aware of the irony of posting that to Twitter)

‚Äúsurpluses are first directed to users; then, once they're locked in, surpluses go to suppliers; then once they're locked in, the surplus is handed to shareholders and the platform becomes a useless pile of shit‚Ä¶this is the enshittification lifecycle‚Äù https://t.co/ZJPGuYqkoL

@BenPhillips_ANU @TristanAR_ @jryancollins has led some great research in the carbon cost of new build in the UK https://t.co/ILgNdRXn1W ie building what‚Äôs promised would blow the whole carbon budget for the UK. Do we have equivalent research for Aus?

@BenPhillips_ANU @TristanAR_ Agreed with this. Land appreciates (generally), housing depreciates. And building is only cheap as we kick we can down the road on cost, and/or we privatise the profit and socialise the costs‚Äîinfrastructure provision cost is huge, never mind environmental (+health etc) costs
And the main project site is here: https://t.co/EuRzFjBLla

I just wrote a piece about a new project I'm part of, called Circular Design Praxis, based out of Japan, but with an Asia-Pacific lens on circularity. Here's my essay contribution‚Äîhope you find it interesting, useful or otherwise provoking! https://t.co/V1iPhWbJfi
Something we‚Äôre proud to sponsor through our school - have a think about entering, and/or pass it on! https://t.co/OVNX8PRurI  https://t.co/OVNX8PRurI

‚ÄòThe Shortest History of England‚Äô, by James Hawes, is great. As with his equivalent on Germany, Hawes is brilliant at explaining how ancient fault lines endlessly shape politics, culture and identity. In particular here, how ‚Äòthe UK‚Äô, ‚ÄòBritain‚Äô and ‚ÄòEngland‚Äô can never hold. https://t.co/eI5TSIywO3

@om @tomcoates @margarethowell @Sunspel Want @om said. The clothes are expensive but I literally have 20 year old shirts from @margarethowell which are still great. The truly sustainable choice! @gquaggiotto @martinsw Japan is the first major #slowdown country; its movement into that, with false starts, resistance, brilliant regeneration and intriguing experiments, is fascinating. @Fractal10 Of course. Australia lagging well behind there too, but could leapfrog many others if it got its act together.

(This research doesn‚Äôt note the need to reduce traffic noise ‚Äî though it does point to the lack of green space in cities, for us and birds. So let‚Äôs reimagine our biggest shared public spaces in cities ‚Äî our streets ‚Äî as bird sanctuaries, for us, them, and multiple other things)

(In my relentless varied provocations about reframing ‚Äòvalue‚Äô of streets, the inverse relationship between traffic noise and birdsong is almost always the research that grabs peoples‚Äô imagination. Here‚Äôs yet more research on *some* of what birdsong does) https://t.co/0K2WcHFUbG

@ImmyKaur That‚Äôs very kind, Immy, and much appreciated (and returned back atcha, about your work!) I feel like I‚Äôve been unusually ‚Äòhead-down‚Äô recently, engaged in understanding a new organisation, context, culture etc, but hope to surface with further thoughts, ideas, insights soon!

@sam__rye Indeed. In the book there‚Äôs also sections on speculative narratives, how to use them, etc. And of course, shifting narratives (and thus addressing belief systems, ideologies, motivations) was also core, as we took a design-led approach: design always involves itself in narratives

@ImmyKaur @sam__rye The one-minute city aspect gets a reference in a couple of pages reflecting on building engagement, awareness etc. But could actually be a book in its own right (!!!) and is now a focus of my current work, I guess. Here, it‚Äôs just a minor note - but it cut-through globally

@ImmyKaur @sam__rye Thanks v much to both of you - it‚Äôs appreciated. I‚Äôm going to write more about it sooner or later (haven‚Äôt really done that yet) but it was really a case of writing it up as I was going, and then rewriting, reframing etc. So it was very much part of the process of doing.

@gregorg @FiveiPads @roryhyde Absolutely. And Dyer is a great example of working with subjective positions and cultural criticism. ‚Ä¶ and most policymaking practice (I‚Äôm not going to mention much media and politicians). (From another context) this is very good on the need to recognise that everything is context https://t.co/m0I602Qfxo

Which may ultimately be the main useful takeaway. As everything is culture, what works is only ever local and cannot simply be deployed elsewhere. What works in Stockholm may not work in Malm√∂, never mind Melbourne, Montreal or Manila. Thus the fallacy of ‚Äòwhat works‚Äô ‚Ä¶

But having been there throughout, a lot of it has worked very well, given a more holistic public health agenda was guiding it. I‚Äôm so loathed to get into it publicly due to the hysteria stirred up elsewhere, and equally, what worked there will not work anywhere else.

Only posting this as a saw several friends had ‚Äòliked‚Äô it. There are many things to learn from the strategy, and many things unique to Sweden, and many things that have or could turn out to be errors, and all points in between. It‚Äôs too early to declare success or failure ‚Ä¶

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw It‚Äôs not only grounded (although I like Latour‚Äôs use of that) but also owned, deeply participative, co-produced, meaning-full, care-full, legible, adaptable, tending to resilient etc etc. That‚Äôs a quite different sensibility and practice, I think.

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw Maybe. And completely shifting the emphasis there, to resist scaling to abstractions rather than go for it, and instead enable specific places, peoples to construct their own systems, cultures, things (that shifts our role as designers). Learning might be shared, but ground-up

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw @cbr_heartdoc @summerscope Right. Or at least let‚Äôs think about scale more carefully ie Murray/Darling requires a response at that scale; a community centre is another scale again. Hence my one-minute city provocation, within 15, within 30 etc etc. (Ta for paper; looks good!)

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw What I meant by ‚Äòlossy‚Äô. Each step of abstraction loses detail, creates waste, homogenises etc That‚Äôs where the rot sets in, whether a hospital triage process or farming or a public building or a cemetery etc Collaborating on ground-up instead asks good questions about specifics

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw @cbr_heartdoc So I‚Äôm querying the idea that homogeneity dropped onto other contexts (the starting comments) is a good idea ‚Äî and asking for greater specificity with that reality, working with that grain, whether your street, Melbourne, the Murray/Darling etc and resisting careless scaling

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw @cbr_heartdoc It‚Äôs how we think about scale in a less hierarchical (or colonial) sense - ie local is interdependent with other scales too, but at least that local or regional scale enables participation, groundedness, diversity rather than homogeneity, adaptation etc

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw So not to say one can‚Äôt learn from that ‚Äòreality‚Äô level (which I still have a problem with!) and test that learning elsewhere (some other bit of reality? Recognising it‚Äôs all interdependent‚Ä¶) but it‚Äôs a very different practice to deploying, scaling, reproducing etc

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw And of course makes problematic a lot of previous/current ideas of industry and commerce! But, we can see where that has led, in most cases, with ‚Äòexternalities‚Äô simply ignored in that lossy process. And those externalities, for want of a better word, are social, environmental

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw Precisely. But I‚Äôd also say it‚Äôs relevant for any ‚Äòdesign for policymaking‚Äô work (abstracting up only leads to national solutions rather than regional or local specificity, and we can see where that heads) or anything to do with design for living environments, built environment‚Ä¶

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw So I‚Äôm getting precisely at that ‚Äòwe rendering something somewhere new‚Äô sensibility ‚Ä¶ (and I know you‚Äôre very aware of that, @overlobe, given your location!) Think we have to seriously question many of those instincts, habits or practices now (again, Liboiron worth a read!)

@overlobe @jamiemill @indiyoung @camerontw Indeed that makes sense for some things, but increasingly clear that perhaps only ground-up (as opposed to ‚Äòscaling‚Äô, top-down, or colonialism in certain contexts) would enable or create richer, adaptive, specific, resilient, participative, ethical, diverse possibilities

Addressing a range of scenarios there would question some of the other ‚Äòcertainties‚Äô ie need for natural gas. Similarly, nuclear may well have a role, as some component of backup baseload, but perhaps not two extra new plants. And so on.

@noelito @IndyJohar So again, blurring and shifting relationships between those different cultures of decision-making - not at all hard boundaries - but they more from representative to participative, from common to diverse, from big to small, heavy to light, slow to fast, fixed to@malleable etc

@noelito @IndyJohar Or religion:

60 minute: city cathedral/mosque
30 minute: major synagogue
15 minute: local chapel
1 minute: Shinto shrine tucked between two buildings in a side street ‚Ä¶

‚Ä¶ and so on

@noelito @IndyJohar Or football:

60 minute: big stadium
30 minute: sports centre
15 minute: school pitches used by communities around 
1 minute: kids playing in street

@noelito @IndyJohar eg We can stretch organisation of ‚Äòhealth‚Äô across these nested relationships:

60 minute: major hospital
30 minute: health centre
15 minute: doctors‚Äô surgeries
1 minute: trees, neighbours

Lower are more participative, malleable; former are more representative, ‚Äòheavier‚Äô

@noelito @IndyJohar Def. I guess I‚Äôm reinforcing that the 15 minute scale is bit more about the municipality, by definition. Not fully, the the emphasis skews there. You can cycle a long way in 15 mins (3km?) and so your relationship is not so intimate, involved. Health stretches across those scales
@noelito @IndyJohar Need to write all this up! There‚Äôs something emerging, as nested organisation of scales and paces, and I‚Äôll need to write it and draw it to figure it out properly ‚Ä¶

@noelito @IndyJohar That moves up through the gears from that point - 1‚Äô, 15‚Äô, 30‚Äô, 60‚Äô etc - with representative decision making cultures at latter larger scales (subways, stadia, cathedrals, hospital etc) and participative at smaller scale (bike, street football, shrine, tree)

@noelito @IndyJohar ‚Ä¶ and thus those must be participative and constructed by people themselves - which is appropriate at neighbourhood scale, block scale, street scale ie one-minute ‚Ä¶ which means more participative model, people author/grow their own city at that scale and intimacy

@noelito @IndyJohar So it must average out, by definition, which is why the concept is very strong way of thinking about municipal services, amenities, infrastructures etc. It‚Äôs very useful in that respect. But for increased diverse and differentiated experiences you need to zoom in ‚Ä¶

@noelito @IndyJohar The interesting thing about 15 mins City if from peoples‚Äô perspective (needs/desires) is that there‚Äôd be infinite overlapping, constantly shifting views (as needs change, and people are different.) So it‚Äôs not really a tightly defined district. That‚Äôs v powerful. But also tricky

@noelito @IndyJohar I‚Äôve written a narrative, a few years ago for Melbourne, which is more from neighbourhood view (actually, many variations on it, but the Melbourne one is most developed), covering 24 hours. I‚Äôll post this weekend, I think.

@noelito @IndyJohar That‚Äôs less-likely, as the 15-minute view IS from the point of view of the neighbourhood, actually the municipality. It‚Äôs from that perspective, by definition. You need one-minute perspective (temporal and spatial) to get down to street level, person/animal level ‚Ä¶

@debcha What I‚Äôve found, when trying to get these ideas through (eg urban projects in Amsterdam, Stockholm, London etc) is that the old guard of big infra/planning resists this hugely - for obvious reasons perhaps. And it will mean a huge transfer of value I suspect. But not a total one.

@debcha Totally. There could be such a powerful, meaningful relationship between a baseload/backup layer from centralised structures (also socially binding across places) and then distributed/super-local for variable loads ‚Äòon top‚Äô. Maps onto mobility, energy, waste, maybe water etc

@biancawylie @debcha Again, the interplay between community/place and public/society, mapping against non-grid and grid, variously, allowing for diverse scales of decision-making, ownership, culture, material, resource flows etc ... 'infra', in which we can activate the mundane

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Nee build at apartment scale (or under streets) automated vacuum disposal though I‚Äôm not a fan as it‚Äôs not adaptive (cf Japanese building lifespan note), expensive, and does nothing to have people confront their waste. @ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger No wheelie bins on streets at all this way, including on old streets of some equally old buildings. @ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger 2) Build recycling bins at neighbourhood-scale, which people walk their smaller leftovers to through now-pleasant streets (how it happens across much of Europe) Make these engaging community hubs. @ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger That means 1) reducing waste massively by enforcing only reusable or biodegradable packaging (legislation and incentive on supplier side, through to retail). Ensure composting/fermentation for food. Build repair and reuse services in your rapidly emptying high street spaces.

@ArchiFuturist @deljanai @cyclingtiger Back to bins (where we came in) the real answer is not architecture narrowly oriented around buildings, but assessing the architecture of the problem. @johnthackara The alternative to that starting at the national level as per the paper, which tends towards fiscal changes and supports things like EVs (typically). So the snowball is the ‚Äòother side‚Äô I was alluding to, wherein we demonstrate compelling evidence of another way, then build

@johnthackara Good point on biomass. My point on snowballs if we have to show the value of more considered approach - indicating shifting lifestyles, for instance - which you can then take to national politics, with evidence. So it starts small and local, but builds towards national.

@johnthackara Well, indeed. It does depend on which mission you start rolling your snowball towards. Ours has been to streets as the focus, rather than vehicles, opening up many more ways foreword - including fewer motor vehicles in total (something Volvo CEO recently endorsed)

I call this a 'snowball principle', in which experiments and prototypes designed to scale generate compelling evidence as they go (if you help), thus opening up the strong possibility of building political capital (and so fiscal policy scaffolding) over time rather than at step 1 https://t.co/WrE5TwpNAb

The other side is in locating, initiating, nurturing, driving and spreading small scale changes into portfolios. That's where we've started ‚Äî¬†which means a broader playbook of social, cultural and technological measures, around which a fiscal scaffolding can subsequently emerge.

This is v important; it indicates one side of the equation ‚Äî¬†concerning fiscal measures of tax and subsidies ‚Äî¬†is proven, here at least, given different evaluation, and starting point of small scale changes that tip upwards.

"Similarly, the opportunity to activate upward-scaling tipping cascades will be missed if the value of decarbonisation policies is judged only on their immediate effects." So the tendency to immediate effects is counter-productive (need long term view + thus different evaluation)

"If carbon prices are set equal to some estimated ‚Äòsocial cost of carbon‚Äô, based on the concept of ‚Äòpricing the externality‚Äô of dangerous climate change these opportunities could easily be missed. The finding and activation of decarbonisation tipping points offers an alternative"

First, that "tax and subsidy policies that bring clean technologies below the threshold of cost-parity with fossil fuel technologies can lead to disproportionately rapid decarbonisation, when applied in a context of other supporting policies."

@anthonymobile I think more than Brexit - but yes, Brexit a factor. General slowdown patterns (falling population rates everywhere), growth not well-handled, other options due to tech etc. As usual, not one driver but multiple combining. And not all bad, I think. A chance to reboot.

@CassieRobinson @catdrew_ @jeneralife That‚Äôs good. But also a tricky business, this; there is value in iterative approaches to transformation (ie building with, and retrofitting, existing systems, from within. This is one of the clear motives behind the ‚Äòone-minute city‚Äô theory and practice: to better understand, and show, how to radically increase biodiversity around us, in order to continually regenerate biodiversity (including us)

Even if a proxy, as this is across 26,000 Europeans across different contexts ‚Äúit may prove that managing for bird diversity is a win-win strategy, with both humans and birds benefitting from management actions that promote a high diversity of natural landscape features‚Äù

Obviously there are caveats, and the usual causation/correlation issues, particularly with something as ‚Äòslippery‚Äô (flighty?) as researching the presence and impact of bird species across spatial dimensions, but still, the researchers address that as best they can at this point

‚ÄúAn increase in bird species richness by 10% (equivalent to approx. 14 bird species at the median of 136 bird species) is related to an increase in life-satisfaction by a value of 0.052, while an increase in income by 10%‚Äù (Birds versus salaries?)

‚ÄúOur results show that bird species richness is positively associated with life-satisfaction across Europe ... the effect of bird species richness on life-satisfaction may be of similar magnitude to that of income.‚Äù (Well, this is interesting) https://t.co/GwTi05yQRx
